text: the exodus from Ramadi fleeing the march
of Islamic state into their City and
across the bridge towards Baghdad has
become a symbol of the desperate and
often elusive search for sanctuary in
Iraq more than a hundred thousand people
have come his way in the last two weeks
they've driven and walked and been
wheeled to safety
[Music]
those who could brought a handful of
possessions many like four-year-old
rhemas and her family came with just the
clothes on their back we heard some
noise people saying just get out Islamic
state is coming I got my father and my
family and left we've been here for two
days but there won't let us cross into
Baghdad while many were allowed in
others were held back the authorities
afraid the militants might use the chaos
to slip into the capital there's little
dignity here the old and for the infirm
it's not the picture of progress many
like to paint
on Mohannad has been on the move for
five months an old lady who wonders what
she's done wrong to deserve this this is
so unfair she says angry and upset of
what's happened to her the pension asked
if the world was watching
does America accept this she said do
other countries just a few weeks ago the
Iraqi government and the White House
were touting their success in pushing
back Islamic state but in the last few
days the militants have turned the
tables in Ramadi America's top military
commander says the city isn't central to
the future of Iraq well tell that to the
thousands and thousands of people who
run for their lives and fled along this
road over the last few days it certainly
doesn't look like success the more than
a weak government forces have fought
back
but the battle against Islamic state is
slower and harder than imagined some
areas have been retaken allowing people
to go home
but this is why so many are afraid to
return his Lama k-state's is said to
have slaughtered more than 1700 soldiers
in Tikrit last June they were captured
when the militants swept through Iraq
last summer we visited the site where
they're thought to have been killed the
stench betrays the horrors that still
lie beneath waiting to be exhumed many
of the young soldiers were led down to
the river where they were shot or
beheaded and dumped into the Tigris it
was the worst single incident in a wall
already littered with atrocities
at times it feels as though the country
has lost its moral compass sheer
paramilitaries came here to honor their
dead comrades and to prepare for the
battles ahead after twelve years of war
in Iraq only more death seems guaranteed
Ian's panel BBC News Tikrit
